paper_metadata.title: LIGHTING THE WA Y OR STEALING THE SHINE? AN EXAMINATION OF THE DUALITY IN STAR SCIENTISTS‚Äô EFFECTS ON FIRM INNOVATIVE PERFORMANCE
paper_metadata.research_context: Study of 456 dedicated U.S. biotechnology firms between 1973 and 2003, examining patenting outcomes and inventor-level data

constructs.definition: Operationalized as a dummy indicating whether a firm employs at least one star scientist. Stars were identified using an inventor performance score: InvPerformance = [(InvPatit / IndTenureit) √ó AveForwardCiteit], where InvPatit is the number of patents for which scientist i applied by year t, divided by industry tenure (years since first patent application), multiplied by the average forward citations of the scientist‚Äôs patents received by year t. A scientist whose productivity score is at least two standard deviations above the average of all inventors in the sample is defined as a star. The star firm dummy equals 1 if a firm employs at least one such star scientist.
constructs.context_snippet: Specifically,toidentifystarscientists, we used the following formula: InvPerformance = [( InvPat it IndTenureit ) √óAveForwardCiteit ] ... A scientist whose productivity score is at least two standard deviations above the average of all inventors in our sample is defined as a star. ... We identified 531 star scientists during the study period ... Accordingly, we followed the standard procedure and operationalized the star firm as a dummy variable, where 1 indicates that a firm employs at least one star scientist.

constructs.definition: Measured using successful patenting weighted by impact: patents weighted by citations received in the five years after issuance to account for variance in patents' value. Used as an indication of a firm's innovative productivity following prior research. Models used GLS regressions to relate predictors to this weighted patent measure.
constructs.context_snippet: Following prior research (Ahuja and Katila, 2001), we used successful patenting as an indication of a firm‚Äôs innovative productivity.We weighted patents by citations received in the five years after issuance to account for variance in patents‚Äô value (Sampson, 2007).

constructs.definition: Operationalized as the ability of a firm's non-star scientists to initiate and lead research from innovation to patenting. Measured as the number of unique non-star inventors who applied for patents on which a star scientist was not a co-inventor, adjusted for the number of inventors to avoid bias: Innovative leadership = ‚àë i j √ó ( n n‚àí1 ), focusing on unique inventors who patented without a star (the measure counts unique inventors rather than number of patents).
constructs.context_snippet: Innovative leadership is defined as the ability of a firm‚Äôs members to initiate and lead innovation ... We operationalized innovative leadership as: Innovative leadership = ‚àë i j √ó ( n n‚àí1 ) where ij represents the number of non-star inventors who applied for patents on which a star scientist was not a co-inventor. We corrected for the possibility that the number of inventors might bias the measure. ... our focus was on identifying the number of unique inventors who patented without a star and who had thus demonstrated innovative leadership, rather than the number of patents applied for without a star.

constructs.definition: Defined as the diversification in technological classes associated with a star's patents (the range of technological domains across which the star pursues research). Computed using an (unbiased) Herfindahl-style diversification index across 22 technological fields: Breadth = [1 ‚àí ‚àë_{j=1 to 22} (Nij / Ni)^2], where Nij is the number of patents the scientist has in category j and Ni is the scientist's total patents. For firms with more than one star, analyses used the star with the highest level of expertise breadth.
constructs.context_snippet: We conceptualized breadth of star expertise as the diversification in technological classes associated with a star‚Äôs patents. Using Tzabbar‚Äôs (2009) 22 technological fields, we indexed each field by j=1,‚Ä¶,22 ... Breadthof StarExpertise = [ 1‚àí 22‚àë j=1 (Nij Ni )2] WethenfollowedHall(2002)andusedanonbiased Herfindahl index for citations. As some firms have more than one star scientist, we examined the effect of the breadth of expertise of the star with the highest level of expertise breadth.

constructs.definition: Reflects the frequency and intensity of the star's collaboration with other scientists in the firm, operationalized via co-invention ties. Computed as the average level of co-invention frequency between the star and non-star scientists in the firm: Star collaborative strength = ‚àë_{i=1}^{Ns} ‚àë_{j=1, j‚â†i}^{Ns} z_{ijs} / max(z_{ijs}) divided by Ns(Ns‚àí1), where z_{ijs} (‚àà {0,1,2,3,4}) is the frequency of co-invention between star i and team member j, max(z_{ijs}) is the largest possible number of collaboration ties the star could have within the firm, and Ns is the number of members in firm. Collaborative strength ranges from 0 (no co-invention) to 1 (complete network).
constructs.context_snippet: Consistent with previous research, we examined the breadth and frequency of stars‚Äô co-inventions with colleagues to capture star-colleague collaboration (Uzzi, 1996). Specifically, we computed a star‚Äôs collaborative strength as the average level of co-invention frequency between star and non-star scientists in firms, Star collaborative strength = ‚àë Ns i=1 ‚àëNs j=1 zijs max(zijs),j‚â† i Ns (Ns ‚àí1) where zijs (ùúñ {0,1,2,3,4}) is the frequency with which star scientist i co-invents with team members j ... Collaborative strength varies from 0 (no co-invention) to 1, which would imply a complete network containing all possible ties among incumbent scientists.

constructs.definition: A resource dependence concept describing bilateral dependencies between a star and colleagues; influenced by the importance of the resource each actor holds for the other, the extent of discretion over use of resources, and availability of substitutes. Balanced mutual dependence increases the star's motivation to share knowledge and resources and reduces power imbalances.
constructs.context_snippet: The mutual dependence between two actors is influenced by the importance of the resource that each actor holds for the other actor‚Äôs performance, the extent of each actor‚Äôs discretion over the use of the resources desired by the other actor, and the extent to which the resource or an adequate substitute is available to each actor through alternative sources. ... The relative balance in the mutual dependence (or bilateral dependencies) between a star and his colleagues may moderate stars‚Äô effects on colleagues‚Äô innovative performance (Casciaro and Piskorski, 2005).

constructs.definition: An aspect of resource dependence in which stars' discretion over tacit knowledge and resources creates disproportionate influence over research direction and resource allocation, which can limit colleagues' opportunities for leadership.
constructs.context_snippet: First, we suggest that stars‚Äô discretion over the tacit knowledge underlying the generation of successful innovations and the tangible organizational resources funneled to support a star‚Äôs research create a power imbalance between stars and their colleagues. As a result, stars exert disproportionate influence over an organization‚Äôs research direction and program, which in turn influences other scientists‚Äô opportunities for innovative productivity and leadership.

relationships.supporting_quote: Hypothesis 2a: There is a diminishing positive relationship between the breadth of a star‚Äôs expertise and a firm‚Äôs innovative productivity. At low and moderate levels, increased breadth in a star‚Äôs expertise will improve a firm‚Äôs overall innovative productivity. At very high levels, however, we expect further increases in the breadth of a star‚Äôs expertise to hinder the star‚Äôs ability to help other scientists in their work, suggesting a limit to the positive relationship between the breadth of a star‚Äôs expertise and firm-level productivity.

As predicted in Hypothesis 4a, our results suggest that stars with high collaborative strength increase their firm‚Äôs productivity across all levels of expertise breadth relative to stars with low collaborative strength.

relationships.supporting_quote: Hypothesis 4b: A star‚Äôs collaborative strength moderates the relationship between the breadth of a star‚Äôs expertise and a firm‚Äôs innovative leadership, such that high collaborative strength reduces the negative effect of low breadth of expertise on innovative leadership. In contrast, when the star has an extensive breadth of expertise, high collaboration increases the positive effect of breadth of expertise on innovative leadership.

relationships.context_snippet: As Model 4 shows, the linear effect of the interaction between collaborative strength and the breadth of a star‚Äôs expertise on innovative leadership is positive and significant (Œ≤=0.27; p<0.01), and the square term is negative and significant (Œ≤=‚àí1.89; p<0.01). measurements.name: Patent-weighted productivity (five-year forward citations)
measurements.details: Successful patenting weighted by citations received in the five years after issuance; used as the indication of firm innovative productivity. Citations in the five years after patent issuance are used to weight patents to account for variance in patent value.
measurements.instrument: Patent count dataset cross-referenced with forward citations (five-year window)
measurements.scoring_procedure: Patents for a firm are weighted by the number of forward citations received in the five years after issuance; firm-level productivity is the aggregate weighted patent measure.
measurements.context_adaptations: Applied to biotechnology firms; five-year citation window used to capture patent impact in this context.

measurements.name: Unique non-star inventor leadership count (patented without star)
measurements.details: Count of unique non-star inventors who applied for patents on which a star scientist was not a co-inventor, corrected for number of inventors to avoid bias; focuses on unique inventors rather than number of patents to reflect initiation and leadership.
measurements.instrument: Patent application records parsed for inventor identities and co-inventor presence
measurements.scoring_procedure: Sum of unique non-star inventors with patent applications that do not include a star inventor, scaled by (n/(n‚àí1)) correction as described in Methods.
measurements.formula: Innovativeleadership = ‚àë i j √ó ( n n‚àí1 ) (as described in paper)
measurements.context_adaptations: Designed to separate innovative leadership from increases in overall innovative productivity associated with star presence.

measurements.name: Star identification via inventor performance score
measurements.details: InvPerformance = [(InvPatit / IndTenureit) √ó AveForwardCiteit]; scientist considered a star if InvPerformance is at least two standard deviations above the sample mean; star firm dummy equals 1 if firm employs at least one such star.
measurements.instrument: Patent counts per inventor, industry tenure (years since first patent), average forward citations per inventor
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute InvPerformance for each inventor by year; compare to industry average and standard deviation; label as star if ‚â• 2 SD above mean; update annually.
measurements.validity: Approach follows prior research for identifying star inventors in biotechnology (Zucker and Darby, 2001)
measurements.context_adaptations: Annual updating allowed for non-stars to become stars over time.

measurements.name: Unbiased Herfindahl diversification index across 22 technological fields
measurements.details: Breadth computed as 1 minus the sum of squared shares of a scientist's patents across 22 technological categories: Breadth = [1 ‚àí Œ£ (Nij / Ni)^2]; follows Tzabbar (2009) and Hall (2002) approach for technological portfolio breadth.
measurements.instrument: Patent classification assignments into 22 technological fields (Tzabbar, 2009)
measurements.scoring_procedure: Assign each patent to one of 22 fields, compute shares Nij/Ni, compute 1 ‚àí Œ£ (share^2).
measurements.context_adaptations: Used to capture diversification of star's technological portfolio; when multiple stars present, highest breadth star chosen for firm-level analyses.

measurements.name: Co-invention frequency-based collaborative strength index
measurements.details: Average level of co-invention frequency between star and non-star scientists in firm: star collaborative strength = sum of z_ijs normalized by max possible ties and Ns(Ns‚àí1). z_ijs ‚àà {0,1,2,3,4} denotes co-invention frequency between star i and member j.
measurements.instrument: Patent co-inventor network constructed from inventor lists on patents
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute pairwise co-invention frequencies between star and all other incumbents; normalize by maximum possible tie and number of incumbents; yields value between 0 and 1.
measurements.formula: Star collaborative strength = ‚àë Ns i=1 ‚àëNs j=1 zijs max(zijs),j‚â† i Ns (Ns ‚àí1)
measurements.context_adaptations: Used as moderator and main predictor in analyses restricted to firms employing at least one star.

core_theories.name: resource dependence theory
core_theories.grounding_phrase: From this perspective ... the relative balance in the mutual dependence (or bilateral dependencies) between a star and his colleagues may moderate stars‚Äô effects on colleagues‚Äô innovative performance (Casciaro and Piskorski, 2005).
core_theories.evidence: Used to explain how power imbalance and mutual dependence shape stars' dual effects; explicitly invoked in Hypothesis development and theoretical background.

core_theories.name: knowledge-based view
core_theories.grounding_phrase: In knowledge-based industries, a firm‚Äôs human capital provides the scientific foundation and creative imagination necessary to identify opportunities for knowledge to be combined and recombined (Tzabbar, Aharonson, and Amburgey, 2013).
core_theories.evidence: Used to motivate how specialized expertise and tacit knowledge sharing influence innovation and how collaborative ties facilitate tacit knowledge transfer.

core_theories.name: resource-based view
core_theories.grounding_phrase: By integrating human capital theory with the resource dependence literature, we offer insights for cross-disciplinary assessments of the role that high-status individuals play in the development of a firm‚Äôs human capital and sustained competitive advantage.
core_theories.evidence: Invoked in discussion to situate human capital value as contingent on how it is leveraged within the firm; used to interpret findings on stars and firm advantage.
